articles.headline: Calculated Deal in a Rate-Rigging Inquiry
articles.snippet: Barclays’ admitted efforts to manipulate the Libor appear to be a textbook case of white-collar financial crime, but it led to a nonprosecution agreement.
articles.abstract: Barclays’ admitted efforts to manipulate the Libor appear to be a textbook case of white-collar financial crime, but it led to a nonprosecution agreement.
articles.lead_paragraph: Barclays: Too big to indict?

articles.headline: Options for Savers Seeking Better Rates
articles.snippet: Some consumers, weary of microscopic interest rates, are tempted by potentially riskier options beyond the world of federally insured savings.
articles.abstract: Some consumers, weary of microscopic interest rates, are tempted by potentially riskier options beyond the world of federally insured savings.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’re a saver, you’re probably frustrated, even angry. There’s nothing worse than being punished for good behavior, and that’s exactly how it feels if you’re trying to amass a pile of cash before making a big purchase, particularly when banks pay interest rates that don’t come close to keeping pace with inflation.

articles.headline: MasterCard and Visa Will Pay Billions to Settle Antitrust Suit
articles.snippet: Under the terms of a settlement in a lawsuit over payment processing, merchants can charge higher prices to customers who pay with credit cards.
articles.abstract: Under the terms of a settlement in a lawsuit over payment processing, merchants can charge higher prices to customers who pay with credit cards.
articles.lead_paragraph: Retailers will be able to charge their customers more for paying with credit cards under the terms of a multibillion-dollar settlement announced late in the day on Friday.

articles.headline: Conflict Potential Seen in Genetic Counselors
articles.snippet: As genetic testing becomes more common, an ethical question is raised by the use of genetic counselors, who advise patients, who are paid by the companies that perform the tests.
articles.abstract: As genetic testing becomes more common, an ethical question is raised by the use of genetic counselors, who advise patients, who are paid by the companies that perform the tests.
articles.lead_paragraph: Genetic testing raises some vexing ethical questions, like whether it will cause unnecessary anxiety or lead to more medical procedures, including abortions.

articles.headline: Romney Seeks Obama Apology for Bain Attacks
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney called allegations in an escalating battle over whether his business record included outsourcing American jobs “reckless” and “absurd.”
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney called allegations in an escalating battle over whether his business record included outsourcing American jobs “reckless” and “absurd.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney demanded an apology from President Obama on Friday for making what he called “reckless” and “absurd” allegations in an escalating battle over whether Mr. Romney’s business record included outsourcing American jobs.

articles.headline: Even at a Comics Event, You Can’t Defy Gravitas
articles.snippet: At Comic-Con in San Diego, professors, psychologists and lawyers add dark strokes to a scene of light sabers, superhero costumes and explosion-filled movie trailers.
articles.abstract: At Comic-Con in San Diego, professors, psychologists and lawyers add dark strokes to a scene of light sabers, superhero costumes and explosion-filled movie trailers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — The clouds never lifted at the Comic-Con International fan convention on opening day on Thursday. Inside the meeting halls, neither did the gloom.

articles.headline: Clinton Visits Egypt, Carrying a Muted Pledge of Support
articles.snippet: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton reached out to President Mohamed Morsi but appeared constrained by reluctance to address his struggle with Egypt’s generals.
articles.abstract: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton reached out to President Mohamed Morsi but appeared constrained by reluctance to address his struggle with Egypt’s generals.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton arrived in Egypt on Saturday for meetings with its newly elected Islamist president and the chief of its still-dominant military council, declaring that the United States “supports the full transition to civilian rule with all that entails.”

articles.headline: Vast F.D.A. Effort Tracked E-Mails of Its Scientists
articles.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration captured thousands of messages sent by disgruntled scientists to lawmakers, lawyers and even President Obama.
articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration captured thousands of messages sent by disgruntled scientists to lawmakers, lawyers and even President Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A wide-ranging surveillance operation by the Food and Drug Administration against a group of its own scientists used an enemies list of sorts as it secretly captured thousands of e-mails that the disgruntled scientists sent privately to members of Congress, lawyers, labor officials, journalists and even President Obama, previously undisclosed records show.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Goldman Sachs and the $580 Million Black Hole
articles.snippet: What does a financial giant owe to its clients? That question is at the heart of the battle between the founders of Dragon Systems and Goldman Sachs, their banker, in a sale that went horribly awry.
articles.abstract: What does a financial giant owe to its clients? That question is at the heart of the battle between the founders of Dragon Systems and Goldman Sachs, their banker, in a sale that went horribly awry.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE business deal from hell began to crumble even before the Champagne corks were popped.

articles.headline: For Climbers, Risks Now Shift With Every Step
articles.snippet: In climbing lore, coming back down the mountain safely, rather than reaching the summit, is the ultimate measure of success. Around the world this year, it has been a bad season in that respect.
articles.abstract: In climbing lore, coming back down the mountain safely, rather than reaching the summit, is the ultimate measure of success. Around the world this year, it has been a bad season in that respect.
articles.lead_paragraph: TALKEETNA, Alaska — At 16,400 feet on Mount McKinley, Eric Roche looked toward the summit, still nearly 4,000 feet distant through deep and perilous snow. Then he looked at the picture of his wife and son, mounted on his ice ax and carried through two weeks of climbing. And he changed his mind. He would go home.

articles.headline: Where the Artists Have Superpowers
articles.snippet: Image Comics, founded on the idea of artists having creative and financial control over their characters, is generating much buzz in its industry.
articles.abstract: Image Comics, founded on the idea of artists having creative and financial control over their characters, is generating much buzz in its industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE big debates in comic-book land used to go something like this — seriously:

articles.headline: Here Comes the Catch in Home Equity Loans
articles.snippet: The easy terms of many home equity lines of credit are about to end, as borrowers will have to start paying principal as well as interest.
articles.abstract: The easy terms of many home equity lines of credit are about to end, as borrowers will have to start paying principal as well as interest.
articles.lead_paragraph: IS the housing market finally coming back from the dead?

articles.headline: Two Classes, Divided by ‘I Do’
articles.snippet: Motherhood outside marriage now varies by class about as much as it does by race, and changes in family structure have broadened income gaps and posed new barriers to upward mobility.
articles.abstract: Motherhood outside marriage now varies by class about as much as it does by race, and changes in family structure have broadened income gaps and posed new barriers to upward mobility.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Jessica Schairer has so much in common with her boss, Chris Faulkner, that a visitor to the day care center they run might get them confused.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Building Criminal Cases in Rate-Fixing
articles.snippet: The prospect of criminal cases related to the Libor scandal is expected to rattle the banking world and provide a new impetus for financial institutions to settle with the authorities.
articles.abstract: The prospect of criminal cases related to the Libor scandal is expected to rattle the banking world and provide a new impetus for financial institutions to settle with the authorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: As regulators ramp up their global investigation into the manipulation of interest rates, the Justice Department has identified potential criminal wrongdoing by big banks and individuals at the center of the scandal.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Mark Scott

articles.headline: Leading Role in Obama ’08, but Backstage in ’12
articles.snippet: Penny Pritzker, an heiress who hates being called an heiress, ran Barack Obama’s fund-raising for 2008, but her commitment four years later has become a matter of mystery.
articles.abstract: Penny Pritzker, an heiress who hates being called an heiress, ran Barack Obama’s fund-raising for 2008, but her commitment four years later has become a matter of mystery.
articles.lead_paragraph: At first glance, the party that Penny Pritzker hosted last month in Chicago could have passed for an Obama reunion. Her modernist home and sculpture garden had been the site of Obama fund-raising events over the years, and the guests that night included presidential allies like Rahm Emanuel, chief of staff turned Chicago mayor, and Warren E. Buffett.
articles.byline: By Jodi Kantor and Nicholas Confessore

articles.headline: As Tablet Race Heats Up, Apple May Try Smaller Device
articles.snippet: With new tablets coming from Google and Microsoft, and rumors of one from Amazon, Apple’s response may be to introduce a smaller, less expensive version of its popular iPad.
articles.abstract: With new tablets coming from Google and Microsoft, and rumors of one from Amazon, Apple’s response may be to introduce a smaller, less expensive version of its popular iPad.
articles.lead_paragraph: The tech companies are at it again — trying to catch the blockbuster iPad in a race to win the tablet market.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Nick Bilton

articles.headline: Hollywood Acts Warily at Comics Convention
articles.snippet: To avoid potentially negative press, Peter Jackson showed footage from his coming “Hobbit” film in a conventional format, instead of the boundary-pushing format the movie will use in theaters.
articles.abstract: To avoid potentially negative press, Peter Jackson showed footage from his coming “Hobbit” film in a conventional format, instead of the boundary-pushing format the movie will use in theaters.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Peter Jackson arrived at the Comic-Con fan convention here on Saturday and wowed the crowd with 13 minutes of highly anticipated footage from the first of his two ultraexpensive “Hobbit” movies.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply

articles.headline: Concessions Entangle Universal’s Bid for EMI
articles.snippet: To win regulatory approval, Universal is expected to sell pieces of EMI or its own assets, but analysts are asking whether it will have to sell so much that the deal will no longer be attractive.
articles.abstract: To win regulatory approval, Universal is expected to sell pieces of EMI or its own assets, but analysts are asking whether it will have to sell so much that the deal will no longer be attractive.
articles.lead_paragraph: The endgame in the music industry’s most controversial deal will begin this week in Brussels.

articles.headline: North Korea Experts Can See a Lot in a Hemline
articles.snippet: Analysts are looking at outward signs of a cultural thaw in North Korea, including shorter skirts and high heels, for clues to the thinking of its new leader.
articles.abstract: Analysts are looking at outward signs of a cultural thaw in North Korea, including shorter skirts and high heels, for clues to the thinking of its new leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Keeping track of women’s hemlines is, admittedly, an unusual way to judge the mind-set of a country’s leader.

articles.headline: Microsoft and NBC Complete Web Divorce
articles.snippet: MSNBC.com has become NBCNews.com, ending the site’s brand confusion with the cable channel of the same name and signifying that NBC’s long relationship with Microsoft is over.
articles.abstract: MSNBC.com has become NBCNews.com, ending the site’s brand confusion with the cable channel of the same name and signifying that NBC’s long relationship with Microsoft is over.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Sunday night, MSNBC.com did something that successful Web sites almost never do: it renamed itself.

articles.headline: Surveys Give Big Investors an Early View From Analysts
articles.snippet: Polling analysts on their outlooks for a given company has become a way for large Wall Street firms to discover trading advantages from information that might not be public yet.
articles.abstract: Polling analysts on their outlooks for a given company has become a way for large Wall Street firms to discover trading advantages from information that might not be public yet.
articles.lead_paragraph: They are supposed to be among Wall Street’s most closely guarded secrets: changes in research analysts’ views, up or down, of a company’s prospects. But some of the nation’s biggest brokerage firms appear to be giving a handful of top hedge funds an early peek at these sentiments — allowing them to trade on the information before other investors get the word.

articles.headline: Subway Line Meets an Obstruction: Beverly Hills High School
articles.snippet: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority of Los Angeles in May approved a nine-mile stretch of a project, at a cost of $5.6 billion, that would run under the high school campus.
articles.abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority of Los Angeles in May approved a nine-mile stretch of a project, at a cost of $5.6 billion, that would run under the high school campus.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — The Subway to the Sea, a train that would tunnel more than 15 miles from downtown Los Angeles to the Pacific Ocean, has encountered no shortage of obstacles over the years: from how to pay for it to skepticism about a huge mass transit project in a region that once ripped out trolley car tracks to make way for automobiles.

articles.headline: In Pawlenty, Romney Campaign May Find Down-to-Earth Appeal
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney has embraced Tim Pawlenty, seeking his advice about running against President Obama and dispatching him to Republican events on his behalf.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney has embraced Tim Pawlenty, seeking his advice about running against President Obama and dispatching him to Republican events on his behalf.
articles.lead_paragraph: EAGAN, Minn. — It was four years ago this summer, when Tim Pawlenty ranked high on the list of John McCain’s potential running mates, and Mr. Pawlenty and his wife, Mary, were plowing through a voluminous questionnaire probing deep into their finances and almost every other aspect of their lives.

articles.headline: Latest Word on the Trail? I Take It Back
articles.snippet: Faced with an unforgiving, gaffe-obsessed media culture, politicians and their advisers are routinely demanding that reporters allow them final editing power over any quotations that appear in print.
articles.abstract: Faced with an unforgiving, gaffe-obsessed media culture, politicians and their advisers are routinely demanding that reporters allow them final editing power over any quotations that appear in print.
articles.lead_paragraph: The quotations come back redacted, stripped of colorful metaphors, colloquial language and anything even mildly provocative.
